blog.title: Posts from Redrikki-land
blog.description: Rambling and fic about Star Wars, The 100, Avatar, and whatever fandom strikes my fancy

summary: I just re-watched The Last Jedi on Netflix to see if it was as bad as I remember. Maybe it was the distance, the lowered...
body:
I just re-watched The Last Jedi on Netflix to see if it was as bad as I remember. Maybe it was the distance, the lowered expectations, or the fact I was watching with my Mom who seemed to be having a genuinely good time, but I didn’t hate it anywhere near as much as the first time. Turning off my fan brain and knowledge of pervious films and characters, it wasn’t so bad. 

The visuals were stunning, especially on Crait. My mom loved both the critters, and I can’t blame her because those crystal foxes were so darn cute. If I hand’t known anything about the characters prior to this film, their character arcs would have been interesting. 

Still, there were a few things which continued to irritate me:

1. Costuming. 

In film, costumes are great narrative shorthand for telling us about a character’s status and place within the world of the film. Everyone with the Resistance wears a uniform except Finn, Leia, and Holdo. This is especially weird in Leia’s case considering she was wearing a uniform in TFA except during Rey’s departure. Whatever, the lack of uniform is supposed to tell us that they are not quite part of the Resistance, that there is a distance between them and everyone else. My mom literally thought that Holdo was some sort of politician despite her repeatedly being addressed and referred to as Vice Admiral at multiple points. She is visually designed to be discounted as a military leader and then the film turns around and tells us we suck for doing what she was visually designed to do. 

2. Galactic Politics

The First Order is not the official government, so how the hell are the Resistance rebels? I know I promised to shut off my fan brain, but it was just too much. The Republic and the First Order were two separate governments. The First Order landed a surprise attack on their capital and then had their major super weapon destroyed less than a day later. The film takes place at most a week after that. Where is the Republic military? Are we supposed to believe that every single planet in the Republic capitulated to the First Order in a week or less? WTF?

3. The Bathos

There were so many moments of dumb slapstick humor which just threw me out of the scene and created such a jarring tonal shift. The initial thing with Hux. Finn waking up. You get the idea.

4. The contrived nature of the plot

How are Rey and Kylo Ren in contact? A wizard literally made it happen. Why won’t Holdo share her plan with anyone but that British lady with the nose? Because she doesn’t feel like it and the story needs more conflict. How did Del Toro’s character even know about the transport ship escape plan to sell the Resistance out? Who knows?!  Nothing happens in an organic way and, if I were better at just shutting off my brain and enjoying stories as presented, I probably wouldn’t have minded. As it is…sigh.

title: Wedding Night

read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2lSnjgA

by SpaceTravels

In this series of one shots, we imagine the ways Kylo Ren and Rey could get together.

In this first one, entitled “Wedding Night”, Rey and Kylo Ren have been married for political purposes. This first story picks up on their wedding night, when they must face together the romantic tension that has been building up between them. An evening of bickering, confession, and passion follows.

blog.name: radioactivepeasant
blog.title: Nobody Panic!
blog.description:
Adventures in fandom and creative writing

Here, you'll find a lot of fandom-related posts...and a heck of a lot of writing. So much writing. I do writing prompts just about every weekday, Monday to Friday.

What you're not going to find are posts that insult others or put people down. There's enough of that in the real world: I don't need any on my blog, thanks.

tags: I'm giving Nakari a happy ending
except it isn't an ending because your story doesn't stop just because you become a mom or dad
you can't tell me there weren't a slew of kids named after the heroes of the Rebellion
a bunch of Leias a ton of Lukes a handful of Wedges a fleet of Hans
and in this au the baby known as Luke is going to grow up to be the young man otherwise known as Finn
which would imply tragedy and First Order nonsense BUT NOT IN THIS AU THANK YOU VERY MUCH
in this one he just picks Finn because it was getting too confusing to figure out which Luke people were calling
body:
Fic Prompts: Star Wars Wednesday

Because Nakari Kelen deserved better than she got in that book. I am hereby retconning her fate. Deal with it, Lucasfilm.

Leia smiled when she saw the ship touch down. The Kelen Biolabs official shuttle was looking just a bit worse for wear, but then again, the same could be said for most of the galaxy at this point. The landing ramp lowered and a tall woman sauntered down, pausing briefly to say something to someone still inside.

“Nakari!” Leia put protocol to one side and moved to embrace the other woman.

Nakari grinned and squeezed her back. There were a few lines on each of their faces that hadn’t been there when they’d fought side by side at Endor, a few extra scars on Nakari’s bare arms. Neither said anything about it. The hug ended and Leia pulled back to study her friend.

“It’s so good to see you! How’s the family?”

“They’re great,” Nakari laughed, “Speaking of, where’s my pseudo-nephew? I have a belated birthday present for him.”

“Not a slugthrower,” Leia widened her eyes in mock horror.

It wasn’t a rifle, of course, but since Ben’s birth Nakari had been jokingly threatening to get him a slugthrower rifle – half for Han’s expression of mild outrage and half so “he can be cool like Auntie”.

“Of course not!” Nakari giggled. “I’m childproof. Mostly. It’s a model of the Desert Jewel. Actually flies! The fella outdid himself this time.”

Oh that definitely sounded like something Ben would enjoy. Actually, it sounded like something that Leia would eventually have to ban at the dinner table. But that was alright. Both women looked up with matching grins when there was an exuberant shout from across the landing pad. Luke Skywalker jogged over from the tower to throw his arms around the pair.

“You knew I was coming,” Nakari laughed and hugged him back, “You still act like you haven’t seen me in years!”

“It’s been months!” Luke pretended to pout. “Do you know how many people look at me weird when I do something perfectly normal? I need my Fellow Desert Kid for backup!”

They’d been an item for most of their first year with the Rebellion. It hadn’t ended up lasting, more because of forever being shipped off to different parts of the galaxy, but their friendship hadn’t faded a bit. If anything, it was stronger now.

Nakari rolled her eyes playfully. “Sorry, flyboy, your Fellow Desert Kid was on maternity leave!”

Luke bounced on his heels for all the world as if he were as much a child as his nephew. His eyes sparkled with a hopeful expression, but he said nothing. Leia snorted. Her brother was fairly transparent when he wanted to be.

“Yes, I brought him,” Nakari shook her head in mock dismay. “We all know that’s the real reason you wanted to see me.”

She was, of course, teasing, but Luke still flushed. “I didn’t sense Rolan. He didn’t come?”

“No,” Nakari made an apologetic face. “He really wanted to, though. Dad just has him on too many projects at the moment. He says hi to everyone.” Then her cheerful grin returned. “Be right back.”

She slipped into the shuttle and Leia elbowed Luke playfully. “You get like this about every baby in our group of friends. If you ever start teaching Force Sensitives younger than ten, you’ll be in trouble.” She pursed her lips. “Spoiled rotten, all of them.”

“I’m not that bad,” Luke started to say, then Nakari returned with a little round face peering solemnly out of a blanket. “Ahh oh my gosh, is that the mini-me? What the heck he got huge!”

The baby looked somewhat unimpressed as his mother bounced him lightly. “Look, Lukey! It’s your crazy uncle! Are we gonna be friendly today, or are you gonna barf on him?”

“It would fit the pattern of horrible things happening to Luke’s clothes whenever you’re here,” Leia mused, leaning in to admire the baby.

Nakari laughed as she carefully passed Luke her son. “Yeah this one’s already following in his footsteps. I swear, he goes through clothes so fast!”

“Oh I know,” Leia nodded sympathetically. “Ben was just the same.”

Luke, meanwhile, was thoroughly distracted by his namesake. He adjusted his hold on the tiny boy, making ridiculous faces at him.

“Hey, buddy!” he cooed, “Hi! Did you come to visit Uncle Luke today, huh?”

“Welp, Luke’s gone.” Nakari sighed. “Your Luke, not mine. Though he probably will try to abscond with the smallish one at least once.”

“Oh just wait,” Leia leaned against her friend’s arm in playful camaraderie. “If he turns out Force Sensitive, Luke’s going to start bugging you about letting him teach Lukey early skills. And if he ends up like Ben at all, you will regret saying yes, because Ben spent about a year making every mealtime "the dance of the floating vegetables”.“

Nakari thought of floating noodles and badly cooked nerf steaks and almost choked on a laugh.

Luke bounced on his heels for all the world as if he were as much a child as his nephew. His eyes sparkled with a hopeful expression, but he said nothing. Leia snorted. Her brother was fairly transparent when he wanted to be.

“Yes, I brought him,” Nakari shook her head in mock dismay. “We all know that’s the real reason you wanted to see me.”

She was, of course, teasing, but Luke still flushed. “I didn’t sense Rolan. He didn’t come?”

“No,” Nakari made an apologetic face. “He really wanted to, though. Dad just has him on too many projects at the moment. He says hi to everyone.” Then her cheerful grin returned. “Be right back.”

She slipped into the shuttle and Leia elbowed Luke playfully. “You get like this about every baby in our group of friends. If you ever start teaching Force Sensitives younger than ten, you’ll be in trouble.” She pursed her lips. “Spoiled rotten, all of them.”

“I’m not that bad,” Luke started to say, then Nakari returned with a little round face peering solemnly out of a blanket. “Ahh oh my gosh, is that the mini-me? What the heck he got huge!”

The baby looked somewhat unimpressed as his mother bounced him lightly. “Look, Lukey! It’s your crazy uncle! Are we gonna be friendly today, or are you gonna barf on him?”

“It would fit the pattern of horrible things happening to Luke’s clothes whenever you’re here,” Leia mused, leaning in to admire the baby.

Nakari laughed as she carefully passed Luke her son. “Yeah this one’s already following in his footsteps. I swear, he goes through clothes so fast!”

“Oh I know,” Leia nodded sympathetically. “Ben was just the same.”

Luke, meanwhile, was thoroughly distracted by his namesake. He adjusted his hold on the tiny boy, making ridiculous faces at him.

“Hey, buddy!” he cooed, “Hi! Did you come to visit Uncle Luke today, huh?”

“Welp, Luke’s gone.” Nakari sighed. “Your Luke, not mine. Though he probably will try to abscond with the smallish one at least once.”

“Oh just wait,” Leia leaned against her friend’s arm in playful camaraderie. “If he turns out Force Sensitive, Luke’s going to start bugging you about letting him teach Lukey early skills. And if he ends up like Ben at all, you will regret saying yes, because Ben spent about a year making every mealtime "the dance of the floating vegetables”.“

Nakari thought of floating noodles and badly cooked nerf steaks and almost choked on a laugh.

“It’s so good to see you! How’s the family?”

“They’re great,” Nakari laughed, “Speaking of, where’s my pseudo-nephew? I have a belated birthday present for him.”

summary: Not from Hades' black and universal lake can you lift him. Not by groaning, not by prayers. Yet you run yourself out in a grief...
caption:
Not from Hades’ black and universal lake can you lift him.
Not by groaning, not by prayers.
Yet you run yourself out in a grief with no cure,
no time-limit, no measure.

Why are you so in love with things unbearable?

A Hades aesthetic for our beloved prince of darkness.

na, seid ihr noch ordentlich im WM Fieber? Es ist nur alle vier Jahre WM-Zeit. Und die nächste werde ich wahrscheinlich boykottieren. Insofern gilt es jetzt noch mal die Kuh fliegen zu lassen. Trotz allem…

title: Magnificent View
body:
“See? I told you going hiking was a good idea. Look at that view.” Marin pointed out, setting down her backpack.

“You’re right. This would make a great snipers nest.” Cahira commented, admiring the view.

“Can’t you take a break, just once?” Marin sighed, flopping to the ground and pulling out her water bottle. She took a swig as Cahira sat down beside her and pulled Marin into her arms.

“I’ll try.” She assured her. Marin smiled and leant in, offering her the water bottle.

“Seriously though, if we ever get the opportunity, we should totally stage an ambush here.”
